consent.title: Tilli Assessment | Consent
consent.description: We (at Tilli) are conducting a series of assessments to evaluate a set of core **social-emotional learning (SEL) competencies** in your child. The series consists of two complementary assessments:
consent.parentQuestionnaire: A **parent-report questionnaire**, to be completed by you.
consent.childQuestionnaire: A **self-report questionnaire**, to be completed by your child.
consent.dataUsageTitle: The data collected will be used to:
consent.dataUsage1: Provide teachers and counselors with insights into classroom level learning and developmental needs.
consent.dataUsage2: Contribute to research that informs and improves classroom practices and student learning.
consent.confidentiality1: All data will be **anonymized** prior to analysis and dissemination.
consent.confidentiality2: Personally identifiable information (e.g., your name or your child's name) will not be stored or shared.
consent.consentInstruction: If you provide consent, please **click the button below** to proceed. If you do not wish to participate, you may exit this screen.
consent.privacyPolicy: Read more about our Privacy Policy here.

videoIntro.description: Please watch this short message before continuing.

parentQuestionnaire.title: Tilli Assessment | Parent Questionnaire
parentQuestionnaire.onlyParents: ONLY parents / guardians are supposed to fill this.
parentQuestionnaire.section1: Section 1: Fill demographic details of your child
parentQuestionnaire.section1Instruction: These first questions help us understand a little more about your family's background. This information will be kept confidential.
parentQuestionnaire.section2Instruction: Think about your child’s behavior in the last two weeks as you answer the following questions.
parentQuestionnaire.submissionSuccess: Your response has been recorded successfully.
parentQuestionnaire.thankYou: Thank you for completing, now it is your child's turn

demographic.d1: How are you related to the child?
demographic.d2: What is your child’s date of birth?
demographic.d4: What is the highest level of education you have completed?
demographic.d6: What is your annual household income?
demographic.d7: How many children live in your household?
demographic.d8: How many adults live in your household?
demographic.d9: Which languages are spoken at home? (Select all that apply)
demographic.d10: How often do you read to your child each week?
demographic.d11: What types of screen activities did your child do in the last week? (Select all that apply)
demographic.d12: On average, how much time does your child spend on screens per day?
demographic.d13: On average, how much time do YOU spend on screens per day?
demographic.d14: In the last week, how often did YOU get upset or frustrated about limiting your child’s screen time?
demographic.d15: In the last week, how often did your CHILD get upset or frustrated when you limited their screen time?

screenActivities.gamesAlone: Playing games (mobile, tablet, or computer) alone
screenActivities.videoCalls: Video calls with family or friends
screenActivities.videosWithOthers: Watching videos or playing games with a sibling/adult

question_1.question: In the past week, how often did your child complain or refuse to go to school?

question_2.question: To what extent do you feel the school prioritizes your child's social and emotional needs?
question_2.example: For example, school lessons on managing their emotions.

question_3.question: In the past week, how often did your child talk to you or another adult at home when they were sad?
question_3.example: For example, if they had a bad day at school, do they come to you to tell you how they feel?

question_4.question: In the past week, how often did your child talk to you when they had a problem with a friend?
question_4.example: For example, if your child argues with a friend at school, do they tell you about it when they get home?

question_5.question: In the past week, how often did your child ask for help when they tried to do something difficult?
question_5.example: For example, if they are struggling to build a tower with blocks, do they ask you for help?

question_6.question: In the past week, how often did your child notice when someone at home was feeling sad?
question_6.example: For example, if you look sad or tired, does your child come and ask what's wrong?

question_7.question: In the past week, how often did your child calm down on their own when they were excited or hyperactive?
question_7.example: For example, after running around and playing, can your child sit down quietly without being told repeatedly?

question_8.question: In the past week, how often did your child manage their temper when there was a disagreement?
question_8.example: For example, instead of hitting a sibling who took their toy, do they take a deep breath or come to you to talk about it?

question_9.question: In the past week, how often did your child react calmly when they did not get what they wanted?
question_9.example: For example, if you say 'no' when they ask for more candy, do they accept it without a tantrum?

question_10.question: In the past week, how often did your child notice quickly when you or someone else at home was angry?
question_10.example: For example, can your child tell from your tone of voice or facial expression that you are upset?

question_11.question: In the past week, how often did your child show that they understood how another person felt?
question_11.example: For example, does your child notice when someone is quiet or sad and try to cheer them up with a hug or a kind word?

question_12.question: In the past week, how often did your child try to comfort another child who was crying or upset?
question_12.example: For example, if they see another child crying at the park, do they offer them a toy or pat them on the back?

question_13.question: In the past week, how often did your child try to help another child who was frightened?
question_13.example: For example, if a loud noise scares another child, does your child go to them to make sure they are okay?

question_14.question: In the past week, how often did your child think about what to do before acting when they were upset?
question_14.example: For example, when frustrated with a puzzle, do they pause to think instead of throwing the pieces?

question_15.question: In the past week, how often did your child solve problems with friends or siblings on their own?
question_15.example: For example, if they argue with a sibling over a toy, do they find a way to share without you needing to step in?

question_16.question: In the past week, how often did your child share things with others?
question_16.example: For example, when playing with other children, do they willingly offer to share their toys or snacks?

question_17.question: In the past week, how often did your child listen to others’ points of view during a disagreement?
question_17.example: For example, during a discussion, do they let others speak without interrupting them?
